titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Records of the Asian/Pacific/American Institute RG.21.35
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Lesley Espenship

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2009-05-01T11:13-0400

did.abstract: The records of the Asian/Pacific/American (A/P/A) Institute, dated 1994-2004, document the activities of the Institute and reflect student events, faculty affairs and collaboration with the A/P/A studies program. The collection contains photographs, memoranda, correspondence, student surveys, meeting and conference agendas, syllabi, proposals, posters, flyers, and brochures. It also includes audio cassettes, VHS tapes, and mini DVs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is organized into four series:

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Materials transferred to the University Archives in 2007.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: There may be some restrictions on the use of the collection. For more information, contact: New York University Archives Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 70 Washington Square South New York, NY 10012

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
New York University Archives
Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, New York 10012
Phone: 212.998.2641
Fax: 212.995.4225
E-mail: nancy.cricco@nyu.edu

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Records of the Asian/Pacific/American Institute; [Call]; box number; folder number;

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Asian/Pacific/American (A/P/A) Institute was founded in 1996 in response to student interest combined with New York University’s commitment to global excellence. The Institute is focused on community and intercultural studies within a broad, rigorous international and comparative framework.

The A/P/A Institute incorporates the ideas of the NYU Asian/Pacific/American studies program and local, national, and international affairs into public events and symposia for the larger New York University and New York City communities. The Institute brings together accomplished scholars, community-builders, and artists from New York City and beyond for events throughout the year including conferences, seminars, book readings, film screenings, musical performances, and brown bag lunches. The Institute also co-sponsors events with student and community organizations, which serve as educational programs to complement the academic Program and address the needs of the community at large.

The A/P/A collaborated on several events and activities with the Office for African American, Latino, and Asian American Student Services (OASIS). OASIS was created in 1988 in response to the expressed needs of students of color for more University administrative support and commitment. Today the mission of OASIS continues to be carried out by the Center for Multicultural Education and Programs (CMEP) at NYU.

list.item: New York University. “Asian/Pacific/American Studies: The Institute.” http://www.apa.nyu.edu
New York University. “Center for Multicultural Education and Programs: About Us.” http://www.cmep.nyu.edu

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The records of the Asian/Pacific/American (A/P/A) Institute, dated 1994-2004, document the activities of the Institute from its founding in 1996 and reflect student events, faculty affairs and collaboration with the A/P/A studies program. The collection contains photographs, memoranda, correspondence, student surveys, meeting and conference agendas, syllabi, proposals, posters, flyers, and brochures. It also includes audio cassettes, VHS tapes, and mini DVs.
The collection is divided into four series: 1. Conference; 2. Administrative; 3. Events; and 4. Photographs.

Series I: Conference. Series contains information on the preparation and production of the Asians in America conference from 1994-1998, as well as other conferences of interest to the A/P/A community. The records generally pertain to conference logistics, planning, and publicity.
Series II: Administrative. Series is divided into three subseries which relate to specific A/P/A staff members.

Subseries A: Sheelagh Cabalda. Contains records pertaining to Cabalda's work at the Office for African American, Latino and Asian American Student Services (OASIS) and in collaboration with A/P/A. This subseries documents various conferences, workshops and events produced by OASIS, A/P/A and other institutions. These records provide an understanding of student activities and events related to A/P/A Institute.

Subseries B: Tomio Geron. Contains correspondence, memoranda and reports related to the further development of the A/P/A studies program, major and minor. This includes new course proposals, staff and faculty job descriptions, mission statement, departmental magazine and creation of an alumni association. These records reflect the planning involved in the ongoing development of the academic program.

Subseries C: Risa Morimoto. Includes general course information related to the A/P/A program in addition to various events sponsored by the department. This subseries contains syllabi, course evaluations, course proposals and event records.

Series III: Events. Series consists of information regarding various events and activities produced and sponsored by the A/P/A Institute. These records are primarily comprised of outreach materials such as posters, brochures, and flyers. The majority of these events are art related, such as gallery exhibitions, author reading series, and film screenings. Events also include lectures and discussions regarding various issues relevant to the A/P/A student community. Many of these events were documented either on film or audio. These recordings are included in the collection. This series is divided into three subseries: 1. General (alphabetical), 2. Posters, and 3. General (chronological). Subseries 3 consists of general events material that was recieved at a later date and its chronological organization has been retained.
Series IV: Photographs. This series includes images of various events, students, faculty, and staff of the A/P/A Institute and the A/P/A studies program.
